Package org.neo4j.internal.batchimport.cache.idmapping.string

Class EncodingIdMapper

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.neo4j.internal.batchimport.cache.idmapping.string.EncodingIdMapper
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable, IdMapper, MemoryStatsVisitor.Visitable
    public class EncodingIdMapper
extends Object
implements IdMapper
    Maps arbitrary values to long ids. The values can be added in any order, but needs preparation in order to get ids back later. In the preparation phase the added entries are sorted according to a number representation of each input value and get(Object, Group) does simple binary search to find the correct one. The implementation is space-efficient, much more so than using, say, a HashMap. Terminology... there's a lot going on in here, and to help you understand the code here's a list of terms used in comments and variable names and some description what each generally means (also applies to ParallelSort btw): - input id: An id coming from the user that is associated with a neo4j id by calling put(Object, long, Group). the first argument is the id that the user specified, the second is the neo4j id that user id will be associated with. - encoder: Encodes an input id into an internal, more space efficient representation (a long) of that input id. - eId: The internal representation of an input id, generated by an encoder. - data cache: An array of eIds. eIds are added in the order of neo4j ids, i.e. in the order in which they are put. - tracker cache: An array where every array item is a pointer to an index into the data cache it's set to track. After the data cache has been filled the eIds are sorted. This is done by _not_ sorting the data cache, but instead sorting the tracker cache as a proxy to its data cache. The reason it's done like this is that id spaces (Group) are kept as data cache ranges, since all ids for any given id space must be added together before adding any id for another id space. - collision: Since eId has potentially fewer bits than an input id there's a chance multiple different (or equal) input ids will be encoded into the same eId. These are called collisions.

      • get

        public long get​(Object inputId,
                Group group)
        Returns the data index (i.e. node id) if found, or -1 if not found.
        Specified by:
        get in interface IdMapper
        Parameters:
        inputId - the input id to get the actual node id for.
        group - Group the given inputId must exist in, i.e. have been put with.
        Returns:
        the actual node id previously specified by IdMapper.put(Object, long, Group), or -1 if not found.

      • put

        public void put​(Object inputId,
                long nodeId,
                Group group)
        Description copied from interface: IdMapper
        Maps an inputId to an actual node id.
        Specified by:
        put in interface IdMapper
        Parameters:
        inputId - an id of an unknown type, coming from input.
        nodeId - the actual node id that the inputId will represent.
        group - Group this input id will be added to. Used for handling input ids collisions where multiple equal input ids might be added, as long as all input ids within a single group is unique. Group ids are also passed into IdMapper.get(Object, Group). It is required that all input ids belonging to a specific group are put in sequence before putting any input ids for another group.

      • needsPreparation

        public boolean needsPreparation()
        Specified by:
        needsPreparation in interface IdMapper
        Returns:
        whether or not a call to IdMapper.prepare(PropertyValueLookup, Collector, ProgressListener) needs to commence after all calls to IdMapper.put(Object, long, Group) and before any call to IdMapper.get(Object, Group). I.e. whether or not all ids needs to be put before making any call to IdMapper.get(Object, Group).

      • prepare

        public void prepare​(PropertyValueLookup inputIdLookup,
                    Collector collector,
                    ProgressListener progress)
        There's an assumption that the progress listener supplied here can support multiple calls to started/done, and that it knows about what stages the processor preparing goes through, namely:
        1. Split by radix
        2. Sorting
        3. Collision detection
        4. (potentially) Collision resolving
        Specified by:
        prepare in interface IdMapper
        Parameters:
        inputIdLookup - can return input id of supplied node id. Used in the event of difficult collisions so that more information have to be read from the input data again, data that normally isn't necessary and hence discarded.
        collector - Collector for bad entries, such as duplicate node ids.
        progress - reports preparation progress.

      • detectAndMarkCollisions

        private long detectAndMarkCollisions​(ProgressListener progress)
        There are two types of collisions: - actual: collisions coming from equal input value. These might however not impose keeping original input value since the colliding values might be for separate id groups, just as long as there's at most one per id space. - accidental: collisions coming from different input values that happens to coerce into the same encoded value internally. For any encoded value there might be a mix of actual and accidental collisions. As long as there's only one such value (accidental or actual) per id space the original input id doesn't need to be kept. For scenarios where there are multiple per for any given id space: - actual: there are two equal input values in the same id space ==> fail, not allowed - accidental: there are two different input values coerced into the same encoded value in the same id space ==> original input values needs to be kept
        Returns:
        rough number of collisions. The number can be slightly more than it actually is due to benign races between detector workers. This is not a problem though, this value serves as a pessimistic value for allocating arrays to hold collision data to later sort and use to discover duplicates.

      • markAsCollision

        private boolean markAsCollision​(long nodeId)
        Returns:
        true if marked as collision in this call, false if it was already marked as collision.
